p: In a previous clinical trial of an experimental inactivated RRV vaccine, immunized individuals produced neutralizing antibodies in serum that conferred protection in mice during subsequent passive transfer studies [ 14– 16]. In addition, several murine mAbs that bind to RRV have been reported, although functional characterization of these mAbs generally has been limited [ 17– 20]. The mature alphavirus glycoprotein is composed of the E1 and E2 envelope proteins in a heterodimer, which is expressed as a trimeric spike on the virus surface after cleavage of the E3 protein by furin-like proteases [ 21]. Neutralization escape mutants have localized the epitopes of mouse anti-RRV mAbs to the B domain and the flanking region within the E2 glycoprotein [ 17, 18, 20]. In comparison, the A and B domains on the E2 glycoprotein and domain II of the E1 glycoprotein of the related alphavirus chikungunya virus (CHIKV) are important targets of neutralizing antibodies [ 22– 24]. However, human monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) specific for RRV have not been reported.
